Pingping,

When Compaq bought Digital, Digital Visual Fortran was renamed Compaq
Visual Fortran. As fas as I know, they are the same thing. I don't get
any warnings when I compile Cantera. 

> I have Digital Visual For6.0 (not Compaq VF6.0) and Micro Visual C 
> 6.0. I was succeed to rebuild cantera.dsw under the directory of 
> ./win32/ based on your cantera 1.3 C++ version, despite about 8000 
> warnings. 


Make sure CANTERA_ROOT is set. Also, make sure you have Cantera-1.3r1.

> When I run it,  I was informed by `input file gri30.inp not 
> found in directory'. Of course, I changed the system variables. 

The MATLAB integrators, CVODE, and DASAC all agree. For examples using
Cantera with the MATLAB ODE integrators, see the MATLAB '.m' scripts in
the 'Cantera/matlab/cantera/examples' directory.

> By the way, once you said that you used MATLAB integrators rather 
> than CVODE to compare with DASAC. The results were in good agreement. 
> What I am interesting is: Can cantera matlab version acts as an 
> interpreter to form a couple of ODEFUN for matlab integrators such as 
> the command [T,Y] = ODE15S(ODEFUN,TSPAN,Y0). If it can, how does it 
> work? It will be excellent if you post the example using matlab 
> integrators.

The reaction mechanism input files are in subdirectory 'data/inputs'.

> Or can specify the exact file in cantera you used to read text file 
> such as "A+B+(M)=C+D+(M)" and to form reaction rate?
